docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Renee Walker was stunned: her 3-year-old patient munched Cheetos instead of easy-on-the-throat ice cream the day after his tonsils were removed. Most parents know that is highly unusual. A tonsillectomy is very painful, limiting what can be swallowed for up to a week. But now doctors like Dr. Walker are searching out new surgical techniques that may ease the sting.
docs.abstract: Doctor explore new surgical techniques to help speed recovery from tonsillectomy (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Cheerleading is not what it used to be. While in the past, cheerleaders were little more than overcaffeinated dancers in itty-bitty skirts, these days they are athletes, real athletes. The head cheerleader is no longer the woman with the cutest smile and shapeliest legs, but the one with the best executed X-out double full twist. (Hint: don't try this at home.) With widespread competitive events, cheerleading has moved from the sidelines tp center court. Last year, more than 75,000 high school participants took part in cheerleading competitions, and the National Federation of State High School Associations says that ''competitive cheer'' is the fastest growing sport for girls.
docs.abstract: Cheerleading is now a more athletic activity than it once was, and cheerleaders consequently are often at risk of serious injuries; more than 75,000 high school participants took part in cheerleading competitions in 1999; ESPN and others televise cheerleading tournaments, which showcase strength, agility and rhythm of participants and feature heart-stopping action; some experts worry that cheerleading has become nearly as dangerous as the sport cheerleaders root for; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Cheerleading is not what it used to be. While in the past, cheerleaders were little more than overcaffeinated dancers in itty-bitty skirts, these days they are athletes, real athletes. The head cheerleader is no longer the woman with the cutest smile...

docs.lead_paragraph: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York decided on a treatment for his prostate cancer, which was diagnosed in April, after months of private deliberation and public speculation. In mid-September, the mayor, along with his doctors at Mount Sinai Medical Center, announced he had received radioactive seed implants during an out-patient procedure earlier that day.

headline.main: More Options, and Decisions, for Men With Prostate Cancer

docs.abstract: Seven men tell why they decided on the kind of prostate cancer treatment they are pursuing; prostate cancer progresses at relatively slow pace, so men in the early stages can take some time to explore expanding treatment options available to them; photos (L)
docs.snippet: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York decided on a treatment for his prostate cancer, which was diagnosed in April, after months of private deliberation and public speculation.    In mid-September, the mayor, along with his doctors at Mount Sinai...

docs.lead_paragraph: People who constantly diet but give in to temptation at the first sight of some rich food learn the hard way that this is a singularly ineffective way to control weight. Now, researchers believe it may also contribute to obesity in their children.
docs.abstract: Researchers believe that parents who constantly diet but give into temptation at first sight of some rich food may be contributing to obesity in their children; have linked serious weight problems in young children with parents who dieted constantly but also binged (S)
docs.snippet: People who constantly diet but give in to temptation at the first sight of some rich food learn the hard way that this is a singularly ineffective way to control weight.    Now, researchers believe it may also contribute to obesity in their children.

docs.lead_paragraph: Most parents now raising questions about the safety and wisdom of childhood immunizations have never seen a case of whooping cough, polio, measles or mumps. Parents now in their 20's and 30's grew up in an era when they and all their schoolmates were protected against such serious infections by a series of vaccinations administered early in life. Few such parents realize that small children can die or become brain-damaged from a measles infection. They do not remember when children were forbidden to swim in public pools all summer so they would not contract polio. Nor have they seen children placed in iron lungs because polio had crippled their respiratory muscles.

headline.main: For the Vaccine-Wary, a Lesson in History

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column says most parents now raising questions about safety and wisdom of childhood immunizations have never seen a case of whooping cough, polio, measles or mumps, having been protected against such serious infections by series of vaccinations administered early in life; warns that ill-informed hysteria about safety of current vaccines could once more bring these awful childhood diseases to the fore (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Federal studies have found a 20 percent higher incidence of asthma in black children than in whites. But a new study suggests that this may be missing the point.
docs.abstract: Researchers find that when children live in an urban setting, regardless of race, they are more likely to have asthma; link may help explain why black children have 20 percent higher incidence of asthma than white children (S)
docs.snippet: Federal studies have found a 20 percent higher incidence of asthma in black children than in whites.    But a new study suggests that this may be missing the point.

docs.lead_paragraph: Delays in the production of flu vaccine have led federal health officials to recommend that the drug first go to people at greatest risk, like the elderly. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said last week that flu vaccine supplies would probably reach last year's level of about 75 million doses. But it issued a series of recommendations to help make sure that if shortages occurred, the vaccine would go to people most in need.

headline.main: Groups at Risk Get Flu Shot Priority

docs.abstract: Delays in production of flu vaccine lead federal health officials to recommend that drug first go to people at greatest risk, like the elderly (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Diabetes affects some 16 million Americans and for many, the consequences can include blindness, kidney disease and heart disease. It may now be possible to learn which patients with diabetes are at the highest risk for serious side effects through the use of a simple blood test.
docs.abstract: Researchers develop simple blood test to help determine which patients with diabetes are at highest risk for serious side effects (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Anyone who has ever tenderly held a young baby is familiar with the instinctive desire to protect the child's head from harm. This is in part because babies' necks are weak, of course, but also because the bones in the skull are not yet fully fused together.

headline.main: A Measure of an Infant Skull's Strength

docs.abstract: Researchers determine just how much weaker an infant's skull is than an adult one, a finding that could have ramifications for range of child-safety devices; photo (S)
